abstract.p: Received November 10, 2009. Received Revised June 17, 2010. Submitted June 21, 2010. Intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) are highly morbid conditions that are common and underrecognized in the intensive care unit. Intra-abdominal hypertension affects the critically ill patient population and is not solely limited to the trauma and surgical subgroups. The recognition of IAH and ACS as distinct clinical states has become more apparent. Extensive bench and clinical research has shed significant light into the definition, incidence, etiology, physiology, clinical manifestations, and treatment strategies. Although further research into this morbid condition is needed, improvement in recognition is a critical first step. This review aims to scrutinize the basic science and clinical literature available on this condition in a surgically focused, organ-system-based approach.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The abdominal cavity is a relatively nonexpandable compartment bound superiorly by the diaphragm, inferiorly by the pelvis, and circumferentially by the abdominal wall. The pressure within the abdomen is normally atmospheric (<7 mm Hg) or subatmospheric (ie, negative) in a spontaneously breathing animal.1,2 Intra-abdominal pathology may lead to increased pressure in this relatively rigid compartment. Although descriptions of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) date back to the early 19th century,3 intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) was first described as a clinical entity in 1984 by Kron et al when they described 4 cases of ACS following abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.4 Recently, definitions for IAH and ACS have been proposed in the literature, which have allowed for more uniform study of these processes. This review aims to scrutinize the basic science and clinical literature available on this condition in a surgically focused, organ-system-based approach.

sec.p: The reported incidence of IAH and ACS depends on the definition used, the patient population, the methodology used to measure IAP, and the frequency with which it is measured. Intra-abdominal pressure, like other physiological parameters, fluctuates during the course of a 24-hour period. However, most studies have based their results on the maximal daily IAP value as opposed to the mean or median value.10 When the mean IAP value is used, the prevalence and incidence of IAH/ACS can be affected by the number of IAP measurements done during the course of a 24-hour period. Malbrain et al suggests using the maximum IAP for diagnosis of IAP/ACS, as the “worst” value should guide treatment.10

The incidence of IAH and ACS varies with the patient population studied. In patients undergoing orthotopic liver transplant, the incidence of IAH (defined as an IAP >25 mm Hg) was 32%.11 In contrast, among general medical–surgical patients the incidence of ACS has been reported to be 4% to 8%.9 In the setting of trauma, early studies reported a low incidence of ACS (as low as 0.5% in some case series).12 More recent studies report an incidence as high as 14% (6% primary and 8% secondary).13 Abdominal compartment syndrome has been described in burn and pediatric patients, with an incidence of 1% to 20% and 0.6% to 19%, respectively.9 Other causes include intra-abdominal infection, pancreatitis,14 and retroperitoneal bleeding.15 In short, ACS is a syndrome that can occur in a broad range of patient populations with a variable incidence.

Factors associated with the development of ACS are heterogeneous and thus, a specific clinical rule to guide clinicians has not been developed. Balogh et al, however, identified anemia, hypothermia, and increased base deficit as independent factors associated with the development of primary ACS.13 In contrast, hemorrhage, high-volume resuscitation, and multiple transfusions are associated with the development of secondary ACS.16 Raeburn et al found that the likelihood of ACS development postoperatively was not dependent on preoperative fluid resuscitation or transfusion requirements but rather on peak airway pressure (PAP) after decompressive laparotomy (DL).17 In a matched cohort study of 22 nontrauma surgical patients, McNelis et al demonstrated that 24-hour resuscitation volume was associated with ACS, but this association did not predict ACS in a multivariate analysis. However, the net 24-hour fluid balance (FB) and the admission PAP were identified as independent risk factors. Using these variables, McNelis et al developed an equation predictive of the probability (P) of ACS development (P = 1/[1 + e−z], where z = −18.6763 + 0.1671 × (PAP) + 0.0009 × [FB in liters]).18 In another prospective trial, Malbrain et al found body mass index (BMI) to be the only factor independently associated with IAH on multivariate analysis.10 Other factors associated with the development of ACS are listed in Table 3 .9,10,13,19

sec.p: The incidence of multiorgan failure (MOF) and mortality is high in patients with ACS. Among trauma patients with ACS, the incidence of MOF is 32% to 55% and the mortality rate is 43% to 64%. In comparison, the incidence of MOF and the mortality rate among trauma patients with equivalent injury severity scores (ISS) who do not develop ACS is 8% to 12% and 12% to 17%, respectively.13,17

As summarized above, ACS occurs in a wide range of patients, and there are a multitude of risk factors for the development of ACS. Given the associated morbidity and mortality, the clinician at the bedside must have a low threshold to consider the diagnosis of IAH and the potential development of ACS.

sec.title: Diagnosis
sec.p: Physical examination has not been shown to be effective at diagnosing the presence or absence of IAH. Two prospective trials report that the clinical estimation of IAH by physical examination had a sensitivity of only 60% for significant elevations in the IAP and was even less sensitive for lower elevations.20,21 These data underscore the need for objective IAP measurement (Table 4 ). This point was endorsed in the comprehensive review by Malbrain and colleagues.22

sec.p: Intravesicular pressure (IVP) is the current gold standard for noninvasive IAP measurement. The pressure is obtained using a transducer connected to the specimen-collection port of a Foley catheter after the catheter has been clamped distal to the port site. Different authors recommend instilling various amounts of saline into the bladder prior to obtaining IAP measurements; volumes range from 0 to 250 mL in animal studies.23,24 The instillation of saline is meant to eliminate air bubbles in the bladder and catheter system.24 Fusco et al demonstrated that the instilled volume affects IAP measurements. A volume of 0 mL demonstrates the least bias in the setting of low IAPs, while a volume of 50 mL results in the least bias at pressures of 25 mm Hg25; thus, Malbrain recommends instilling 50 mL of saline to improve the accuracy of IVP in measuring IAP. Ideally, the bladder should be fully emptied before the instillation of this volume of saline, but radiological studies show that even in the presence of a catheter, the bladder is often not completely empty. Malbrain, in a review, recommends a continuous dynamic monitoring system via a gastric route for those at high risk of elevated IAP and ACS development.22

When measuring IVP, one must keep in mind that the abdominal cavity is not a completely fluid-filled cavity and does not have a constant pressure regardless of position. Instead, the cavity contains solid organs and gas-containing bowel that have an intrinsic weight; thus, changes in position affect IAPs. Patients, particularly those that are obese, should be completely supine when IAP measurements are being done. The pressure transducer also must be zeroed at the iliac crest in the mid-axillary line (analogous to the symphysis pubis) for more accurate monitoring.9,22 Transducer malposition due to patient repositioning may affect IAP measurement. One must also keep in mind that abdominal muscle contraction and low bladder compliance may overestimate IAPs. In order to reduce the effect of abdominal muscle contraction during the respiratory cycle on IAP measurements, it is generally recommended to take the measurements at end expiration when the abdominal muscles are relaxed.22–24 It is also recommended to measure IAP at least 30 to 60 seconds after the instillation of saline into the bladder to allow for detrusor muscle relaxation26 (Table 5 ).

sec.p: Intra-abdominal pressure may be measured directly with an intraperitoneal catheter attached to a manometer or transducer, but clinically direct measurement of IAP is impractical and unnecessary. Indirect techniques of measuring IAP include rectal, inferior vena caval, gastric, and IVP measurements. Rectal pressure measurements do not correlate with directly measured IAP in animal models, and while inferior vena caval pressure measurements do correlate, they are invasive with significant risk of injury and venous thrombosis.27 Early animal models showed poor correlation between intermittent gastric pressure and directly measured IAP,27 but early human studies suggested an acceptable correlation between intermittent gastric pressure and urinary pressures.28 The validity and reliability of gastric pressures have been confirmed by studies of continuous gastric pressure monitors in in vitro and animal models of monitoring IAP.29,30

Traditional methods of monitoring IAP rely on intermittent IAP measurements using indwelling bladder catheters and have shown good correlation with direct measurement of IAP in canine models.23 Intra-abdominal pressure measurements, however, are only “snapshots” of a dynamic parameter; thus, they may not reflect the patient’s true clinical status and may delay the recognition of IAH. Continuous monitoring of IAP, like other pressures, provides the clinician with the greatest insight into the patient’s evolving condition.22 From a nursing standpoint, continuous monitors tend to be less labor-intensive than intermittent IAPs. Also, continuous pressure monitoring eliminates the many variables that affect IIAP measurements described above. Recently, several methods of continuous IAP (CIAP) monitoring have been developed. One method is continuous urinary bladder pressure measurement using a 3-way catheter. Balogh et al and McBeth et al demonstrated the accuracy and reliability of this method in trauma patients and in an in vitro model, respectively.31,32 Using a porcine model in 2003, Schachtrupp et al also found a good correlation between continuous gastric pressure monitoring and direct IAP measurements. The gastric pressures were measured with nasogastric catheters equipped with either a piezoresistive probe or air capsule at the tip.29 While both methods correlated well with IAPs, the air pouch method had the least bias. Using an in vitro model of IAP, Malbrain et al recently demonstrated the validity, reliability, and accuracy of 2 novel catheters that apply this air capsule method of intragastric pressure monitoring (Spiegelberg and CiMON techniques).30 This method is currently being tested on patients in Europe.

sec.title: Cellular and Biochemical
sec.p: Intra-abdominal hypertension not only affects various organ systems (Table 6 ) but also causes derangements at the cellular levels mainly due to neutrophil priming. Neutrophil priming is the enhancement of the neutrophil response to a given stimulus following initial exposure to a different stimulus, so the subsequent activation results in an exaggerated response. Neutrophils in injured patients are primed for cytotoxicity (platelet-activating factor [PAF], tumor necrosis factor α [TNF-α], and lipopolysaccharide [LPS] have been studied as priming agents) through the postinjury activation of p38 mitogen-activating protein kinase (p38 MAPK).33,34 Priming initiates the surface expression of the adhesion molecule CD11b/CD18.33,35 Some studies suggest that ACS-provoked organ dysfunction is mediated by primed neutrophils, endothelial cells, and tissue macrophages.36 Proinflammatory cytokines activate such primed neutrophils resulting in extended superoxide generation and protease release. This action provokes a systemic inflammatory reaction that can lead to organ dysfunction.35,36,37 In various animal models, ACS has been associated with augmented cytokine production. In one such study using a rodent model, ACS alone has been shown to independently elevate systemic levels of interleukin 1 (IL-1), IL-6, and TNF-α.38 In another study that used a swine model, hemorrhage and subsequent ACS has been shown to potentiate a greater cytokine response with elevated levels of IL-1, IL-8, and TNF-α than with either insult alone. This finding may account for the increased rate of MOF and mortality among patients with significant hemorrhage followed by ACS.39

sec.p: The mechanism by which ACS induces cytokine production is unclear, but it may be mediated by gut and liver ischemia.40 Several studies have shown that IAH, even when occult, promotes significant mesenteric ischemia.41,42 In the setting of such ischemic injury, the gastrointestinal tract produces high levels of proinflammatory lipids via the activation of phospholipase A2.43 Levels of IL-6 and TNF-α have been found to be elevated in the splanchnic circulation40 as well in mucosal and serosal intestinal tissues44 following gut ischemia and reperfusion. The magnitude of ischemia and reperfusion injury seems to correlate with the mucosal and serosal cytokine levels.44 Significantly increased levels of IL-10 were found among cells isolated from Peyer patches 1 and 4 hours following hemorrhagic shock, with increased levels of IL-10, IL-1β, and INF-γ (but not nitric oxide synthase, transforming growth factor β [TGF-β], IL-6, or TNF-α) 3 days later.45

The damage caused by ACS has been seen after surgical decompression due to organ reperfusion injury (primed neutrophils) leading to MOF.38 Of interest, melatonin may ameliorate this oxidative organ damage by scavenging free radicals.46

sec.title: Neurologic
sec.p: One of the less recognized organ systems affected by IAH is the central nervous system. Recent studies have demonstrated a strong correlation between IAP and intracranial pressure (ICP) that is independent of cardiopulmonary function.47–49 Two case reports in humans describe this interaction.50,51 These observations may explain some of neurological problems seen in abdominal trauma patients who do not have obvious head injuries.49 This association may also explain the higher incidence of pseudotumor cerebri in obese patients,43,52 the observation that weight loss reduces ICP,53 and the observation that externally applied abdominal decompressive devices can relieve headaches52 and tinnitus.53,54

Animal and human data demonstrate an interaction between intracranial hypertension (ICH) and IAH. In 1996 and 1997, Bloomfield and colleagues demonstrated in porcine55 and swine56 models that IAH causes ICH by increasing the intrathoracic and central venous pressures (CVP), causing functional obstruction of the cerebral venous outflow. This study further demonstrated that either a median sternotomy56 or a DL was effective in normalizing cerebral venous outflow and ICP.55,56 Human studies have shown similar outcomes.48 Using continuous negative applied pressure (CNAP) on a swine model, Saggi et al demonstrated the effectiveness of nonsurgical abdominal decompression in reducing ICP in the setting of IAH.57

The effect of nonsurgical abdominal decompression on ICP has not been evaluated in humans. However, a retrospective study of DL in 17 patients with intractable ICH and IAH demonstrated a reduction of CVP and ICPs by at least 10 mm Hg in all patients and a sustained reduction was observed in 11 patients.58 Nonsurvivors had no sustained reduction in CVPs and only a modest, transient decrease in ICPs. The absence of a decrease in CVP following DL may be a poor prognostic factor. Survivors and nonsurvivors had similar injury severity and abbreviated severity scores as well as similar initial ICPs. Interestingly, the 11 survivors were decompressed when the IAPs exceeded 20 mm Hg and before developing symptoms of ACS. Nonsurvivors had overt ACS at the time of abdominal decompression. Given these findings, Joseph et al suggested that ICH may actually be the first manifestation of ACS and that early abdominal decompression may be a useful approach to such difficult cases. Broad application of this technique is not warranted until larger cohorts of patients have been studied.58

In patients with cerebral hypertension and IAH, the cerebral hypertension should be initially managed medically with hyperosmolar fluids, mannitol, elevation of head of bed, hyperventilation (refractory ICH), cerebrospinal fluid drainage, cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) maintenance with inotropic support to maintain CPP >70, paralysis, and barbiturate-induced coma. In patients with intractable ICH, a decompressive crainiectomy may be considered, but the morbidity of this approach is quite significant. In patients with both intractable ICH and IAH, abdominal decompression may be a useful mitigating strategy. This option is more attractive because the morbidity of DL has significantly improved with the use of a vacuum-assisted closure device with increased fascial closure rate.59 While DL may help reduce ICP, laparoscopy may elevate it because of the insufflation of the abdominal compartment. Laparoscopy should be considered a relative contraindication in patients with known intracranial injuries.47,49,60 And given the 40% coincidence of head injury with major abdominal trauma,60 the use of laparoscopy should be limited in patients with blunt abdominal trauma,47 and when used, restricted to low insufflation pressures.49

sec.title: Cardiovascular
sec.p: Intra-abdominal hypertension causes decreased venous return to the heart by direct compression on the inferior vena cava (IVC). In a canine model, resistance to venous return is highest at the sub-diaphragmatic, supra-hepatic IVC.61 Impairment of venous return occurs at pressures of 15 mm Hg or more.62 In this model, an IAP between 10 and 15 mm Hg was shown to increase venous return as blood from abdominal capacitance vessels is mobilized into the IVC.61,63 The decrease in caval return also causes a decrease in venous outflow from the lower extremities.64–66 There is no proven association between deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and IAH, but the relative stasis of blood flow may be a significant risk factor for DVT.66 Deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis is an important consideration in this patient population, and inferior vena caval filter placement should be considered in patients with IAH who cannot be treated with pharmacological prophylaxis. Pneumatic compression devices in this patient population may be especially beneficial. With the use of duplex imaging on patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy and volunteers undergoing external abdominal pressure of 50 mm Hg, Christen and colleagues were able to demonstrate intermittent restoration of femoral vein flow velocity with pneumatic compression with no effect on femoral vein diameter or pressure.64

As a consequence of IAH, venous return is decreased often resulting in a decrease in cardiac output (CO). In order to maintain stroke volume, a compensatory increase in heart rate is typically seen. As demonstrated by several animal studies, substantial diaphragmatic elevation due to IAH causes further decreases in CO by increasing intrathoracic and pleural pressures.67,68 Increased intrathoracic pressure adversely affect CO by several mechanisms. First, the increased pressure increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload.67 In this setting, a drop in CO may still be accompanied by an increased or unchanged mean arterial pressure. Second, the increased pressure decreases the transmural filling pressure for a given ventricular end-diastolic pressure, thus decreasing the corresponding ventricular end-diastolic volume for a given ventricular compliance. However, ventricular compliance itself also decreases as intrathoracic pressure increases (>30 mm Hg) and causes direct compression on the heart.62 Increased intrathoracic pressure and direct ventricular compression may not only affect ventricular compliance but also disrupt contractility. Diamant et al demonstrated flattening and right-hand side downward shifting of the Frank–Starling curve by IAH and increased afterload.69 Marathe et al conversely did not see flattening and went on to show that decreases in compliance did not occur at IAPs of 5 to 25 mm Hg in a canine model.70 This study indicated that decreases in CO can be mainly attributed to changes in venous return and left ventricular end-diastolic volume, rather than contractility. Yet, in a study by Huettemann et al, an IAP of 12 mm Hg in children undergoing laparoscopy resulted in septal hypokinesia demonstrable on transesophageal echocardiography.71

Decreases in CO in the setting of IAH can be further exacerbated by hypovolemia, inhalational anesthesia, elevated positive end expiratory pressures (PEEPs), and myocardial dysfunction. Hypovolemia62 and anesthesia69 are associated with reductions in CO in patients with IAH. The administration of intravenous fluids tends to mitigate this drop in CO.62,67 Therefore, many trauma surgeons72 advocate volume expansion prior to abdominal decompression in order to counteract the hypotension that often accompanies the associated drop in systemic vascular resistance seen with DL. It is logical that elevated PEEP exacerbates the CO reduction in the setting of IAH as PEEP further increases the already elevated intrathoracic pressure impairing left ventricular function.68,73

The increased intra-abdominal and intrathoracic pressures not only adversely affect patient’s hemodynamics but also disrupt interpretation of hemodynamic variables. Multiple studies demonstrate that measured filling pressures (eg, CVP, PAP, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure [PCWP]) are unreliable in patients with IAH. Typically, these measured filling pressures are elevated due to the increased thoracoabdominal pressures which can fool the clinician into believing that the patient is intravascularly replete when in fact just the opposite is true.67 Using the double-indicator dilution technique on a porcine model, Schachtrupp et al found that a 24-hour exposure to IAPs of 30 mm Hg increased CVP 4-fold while decreasing intrathoracic and total circulating blood volumes by 55% and 67%, respectively.74 This study illustrates that the CVP does not necessarily reflect the intravascular volume depletion that often accompanies IAH. Schachtrupp’s findings verify results of an earlier study by Hachenberg et al which established the reliability of global end-diastolic volume index (GEDVI) and intrathoracic blood volume (ITBV) in 16 patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy.75 Furthermore, Cheatham et al successfully showed that right ventricular end-diastolic volume index (RVEDVI) correlates with cardiac index (CI) significantly better than CVP or pulmonary artery occlusion pressure (PaOP) in the setting of increased intrathoracic pressures which can be induced by ACS.76,77 As a result, resuscitation in this patient population should be directed by volumetric parameters; examples include RVEDVI, GEDVI, CI, and ITBV.70

sec.title: Respiratory
sec.p: Intra-abdominal hypertension causes lower lobe compression atelectasis and increases the intrathoracic pressure.78 Compressive atelectasis caused by diaphragmatic elevation impairs oxygenation by increasing intrapulmonary shunting and dead space ventilation.79 Moreover, increased intrathoracic pressure results in increased pleural and airway pressures (peak, plateau, and mean).79,80 This process also decreases the functional residual capacity (FRC) and may reduce all lung volumes, like other restrictive lung diseases.79 The high pleural and IAPs also reduce static and dynamic lung and chest wall compliance, promoting hypercarbia and ventilatory compromise.79 Furthermore, pulmonary vascular resistance increases with IAH19 due to increased thoracic pressure, decreased FRC, and increased alveolar to arterial O2 difference.79 Simon et al demonstrated in a porcine model that hemorrhagic shock and volume resuscitation exacerbates these pulmonary effects of IAH.81

Intra-abdominal hypertension also increases the risk of ventilator-associated barotrauma. In attempt to recruit collapsed alveoli in patients with IAH, PEEP is usually applied, but the PEEP does not only open the collapsed alveoli, it also potentially overinflates normally aerated ones, resulting in ventilator-induced lung injury. Intra-abdominal pressure and PEEP requirements may be reduced with DL, but prone positioning can worsen IAP.82

Intra-abdominal hypertension promotes the development of pulmonary edema, especially in the setting of coexisting acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). In 2003, Schachtrupp et al found that the extravascular lung water content of healthy pigs increased after subjecting the pigs to 24 hours of IAH at 30 cm H2O.83 Using a pig model, Quintel et al demonstrated that in ARDS, IAH increases the amount of edema.78 The authors applied pneumoperitoneum of 0 and 20 cm H2O in 7 pigs. The whole-lung computed tomography scan and a complete set of respiratory and hemodynamic variables were recorded both in healthy lung and lungs challenged with an oleic acid injury. A pneumoperitoneum of 20 cm H2O significantly lowered the gas content in both healthy and oleic acid injury lungs but significantly more so with the latter. While the same amount of pneumoperitoneum did not increase the mass of healthy lungs, the excess tissue mass (edema) in oleic acid injured lungs amounted to 30% ± 24% of the original tissue weight. The edema was not gravity dependent but instead primarily distributed in the base regions.78

The increased propensity for pulmonary edema in the setting of IAH may be due to increased intrathoracic pressure and subsequent increase in intra-avleolar and interstitial fluid formation as well as decrease in fluid clearance. Intra-abdominal hypertension may also promote acute lung injury and capillary leakage by promoting the release of proinflammatory cytokines (eg, IL-6, IL-1, TNF-α).38

sec.title: Gastrointestinal and Hepatic
sec.p: Intra-abdominal hypertension has multiple hepatic and gastrointestinal effects. It can cause intestinal edema by impairing lymphatic flow,84 but it imparts its most substantial effect on the gastrointestinal tract and liver by causing mesenteric hypoperfusion.42 Mesenteric perfusion is dependent on APP. Abdominal perfusion pressure is defined as the mean abdominal pressure (MAP) minus the IAP (APP = MAP − IAP). In patients with ACS, maintaining APP at 50 mm Hg or more correlates with better survival. Abdominal perfusion pressure has been demonstrated to be a better marker than MAP, IAP, arterial pH, base deficit, arterial lactate, and urine output in predicting survival from IAH and ACS.85,86

Animal studies suggest that mesenteric arterial flow (MAF), intestinal mucosal flow (IMF), hepatic arterial flow (HAF), hepatic microcirculatory flow (HMF), and portal venous blood flow (PVF) all decrease in the setting of raised IAP. In a porcine model, Diebel et al showed that even in the face of a normal CO and systemic blood pressure, HAF, HMF, and PVF fell at IAPs as low as 10 mm Hg. At 20 mm Hg IAP, HAF was 45% of the control value, PVF was 65%, and HMF was 71%.42 Reductions in MAF and IMF are only seen at IAPs of 20 mm Hg or higher. Unlike the liver which has dual blood supply (systemic arterial and portal venous), in the intestine, the microcirculatory blood flow is more susceptible to IAH than the main arterial blood flow, with a 39% IMF reduction seen at an IAP of 10 mm Hg as opposed to only a 27% MAF reduction seen at the same pressure.87 The deleterious effects of raised IAP on intestinal perfusion have been reflected in multiple studies including 6 case reports of fatal intestinal infarction following laparoscopic cholecystectomies. In those cases, bowel ischemia was most pronounced at the ileum and right colon and may be due to splanchnic hypoperfusion, superior mesenteric arterial thrombosis, or inferior mesenteric venous thrombosis (seen more commonly in those patients with atherosclerotic and peripheral vascular disease).88–93

Intestinal mucosal hypoperfusion causes mucosal acidosis that is quantifiable by gastric tonometry. Many investigators have demonstrated that tonometric measurement of intramucosal gastric pH (ipH) is a sensitive indicator for gut ischemia in association with IAH and hypotension.19,87,94 Low ipH is associated with renal impairment, need for re-laparotomy, sepsis, and poor outcomes.94 Studies suggest that mucosal hypoperfusion and acidosis may occur with IAH long before the onset of clinically recognizable ACS, and if left uncorrected, it may lead to intestinal ischemia, ACS, and MOF.19,87 Thus, some investigators have advocated early prophylactic abdominal decompression in patients with low ipH and IAH in the absence of overt ACS to prevent further complications.19

Another early indicator of splanchnic ischemia is serum d-lactate level. Poeze et al demonstrated that serum d-lactate levels correlated well with gastric intramucosal carbon dioxide partial pressure (PgCO2).95 Like ipH, PgCO2 reflects intestinal mucosal ischemia.96,97 Previous to this study, no relationship between serum l-lactate levels and intestinal ischemia had been found. l-lactate, unlike its d isomer, is rapidly cleared by the liver,98 but it is found in the peritoneal fluid early in the course of an ischemic event. Proliferation of d-lactate and mucosal barrier breakdown are well known in septic shock models. While l-lactate is produced by mammalian cells under anaerobic conditions, d-lactate is a by-product of bacterial fermentation and is not produced nor metabolized efficiently by mammalian cells. In an ischemic part of the intestine, the resident microflora rapidly grows, overproducing d-lactate, which enters the systemic circulation as the intestinal mucosal barrier breaks down.95,96 Duzgun et al took Poeze’s findings further and, using a Wistar Albino rat model, demonstrated a positive correlation between IAPs and systemic d-lactate levels, attributed to intestinal ischemia.99 However, despite the elevated serum d-lactate levels, they were unable to demonstrate histological changes consistent with ischemia (except for decreased intestinal wall thickness) at IAPs of 25 mm Hg.99

Hemorrhagic shock resulting in intestinal and hepatic ischemia can lead to sepsis and MOF due to cytokine release and bacterial translocation. Bacterial translocation is the movement of viable enteric bacteria through a permeable mucosal barrier to mesenteric lymph nodes, then to the liver and spleen and then eventually to the systemic circulation. Deitch et al demonstrated that hypoperfusion-induced mucosal permeability is not potentiated by the presence of enteric bacteria; in their study, rats with normal gut flora and antibiotic-decontaminated rats had the same intestinal histopathological changes and the same mucosal permeability to horseradish peroxidase after 2 and 24 hours of hemorrhagic shock.100 Since then, subsequent studies have successfully demonstrated bacterial translocation in the setting IAH-induced intestinal ischemia. Using a rodent model, Diebel et al confirmed that bacterial translocation to mesenteric lymph nodes can occur after 60 minutes of IAP at 25 mm Hg.101 Several other animal studies have demonstrated significant bacterial translocation to mesenteric lymph nodes, liver, and spleen at an even lower IAP.102–105

In addition to intestinal hypoperfusion, mucosal ischemia/acidosis, and bacterial translocation, IAH due to ascites in patients with cirrhosis can exacerbate preexisting portal hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. Rasmussen et al demonstrated in pigs a marked increase in hepatic and portal vascular resistance with IAH >15 mm Hg.106 In support of the notion that the risk of variceal bleeding is increased in patients with higher IAPs, a group of Spanish gastroenterologists demonstrated a significant increase in variceal pressure, radius, volume, and wall tension in 14 patients with cirrhosis in whom IAPs were increased by only 10 mm Hg using inflatable girdles.107

Abdominal hypertension clearly has deleterious effects on the gastrointestinal and hepatic systems, starting with hypoperfusion and acidosis, then resulting in bacterial translocation and eventual sepsis and MOF. Early mucosal hypoperfusion may be detected on gastric tonometry and serum d-lactate levels. In patients with cirrhosis, increased IAPs secondary to ascites can also lead to variceal bleeding and gastroesophageal reflux, underscoring the necessity for aggressive ascites treatment in the high-risk patient.

sec.title: Renal
sec.p: The association between acute renal failure and IAH was first described by Richards et al in 1983,108 but it was noted as early as 1923 by Thorington et al in a canine study of IAP with associated oliguria.109 Recent evidence endorses the notion that IAH is not only associated with but is actually an independent risk factor for renal impairment.110 This was demonstrated for the first time by Surgue et al in a 1999 prospective study of 263 surgical intensive care unit patients in an Australian university hospital. In this study, IAH was identified as an independent risk factor for the development of acute renal failure.110

The mechanism of renal dysfunction in IAH is the result of reduced renal arterial flow and glomerular filtration rate due to increased renal arteriolar and venous resistance. In a 1982 study, using anesthetized dogs, renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate decreased to less than 25% of normal, when the IAP was increased to 20 mm Hg using inflatable intraperitoneal bags. When the IAP was raised to 40 mm Hg, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) dropped to 7% of baseline. Expansion of the blood volume using Dextran corrected the initial drop in CO at 40 mm Hg IAP, but renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate remained less than 25% of normal. Renal vascular resistance increased 555% when IAP was elevated to 20 mm Hg, an increase 15-fold that of systemic vascular resistance. This suggests that the renal dysfunction in the setting of IAH is caused by direct renal vein and cortical arteriole compression and is not related to CO.111 The results of this initial animal study have been validated by subsequent studies.112,113 Ureteral occlusion by IAH does not seem to be an important factor in ACS since renal function does not appear to improve with bilateral ureteral stent placement.114

The changes induced by IAH on renal hemodynamics promote the release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH),115,116 renin, angiotensin, and aldosterone.117 Elevated levels of ADH and aldosterone lead to sodium and water retention, exacerbating IAH, while elevated renin and angiotensin levels augment renal vascular resistance, exacerbating the renal dysfunction. Renin and aldosterone levels decrease with intravascular volume expansion and with DL.117

Intra-abdominal hypertension is of particular relevance in patients who have recently received a renal transplant. As the effects of IAP on renal function have become more widely recognized, transplant surgeons have become increasingly concerned of the effects of pneumoperitoneum on donor kidneys during laparoscopic donor nephrectomies (LDNs). While not clinically significant on either the kidney donor or the transplanted graft, the transplant literature has demonstrated that, like in ACS, patients undergoing LDNs have elevated plasma ADH levels compared to ones undergoing open nephrectomies (ODNs); this appeared to be related to increased IAP.116 More clinically relevant, studies have demonstrated increased expression of endothelin 1 (ET-1), a potent renal vasoconstrictor, in the renal vasculature and proximal tubular cells of kidneys procured laparoscopically. The elevation of ET-1 may account for some of the renal dysfunction observed during laparoscopic procedures and ACS. Antagonism of ET-1 may be beneficial in such patients.118 Furthermore, animal studies from the transplant community demonstrate that pneumoretroperitoneum and raised IAP causes increased oxidative stress in both donor and remaining kidneys in LDN patients.119 While reperfusion does not seem to exert an additive effect on pneumoretroperitoneum-associated oxidative stress, long warm ischemia time and prolonged laparoscopy (>120minutes) augment the effect.120,121 In an attempt to overcome the effects of pneumoperitoneum on donor kidneys, the transplant community studied the feasibility of an intraoperative 3-charge-coupled device (3-CCD) camera to qualitatively monitor renal parenchymal oxygenation122 as well as the effectiveness of using a full-leg intermittent sequential pneumatic compression device to improve splanchnic and renal perfusion during laparoscopy.123 Keeping all that in mind, while LDN results in longer warm ischemic time124 and higher short-term serum creatinine levels in donors and recipients,125,126 long-term donor and recipient renal function are comparable after LDN or ODN124–128 with no histological differences seen between kidneys procured by laparoscopic or open surgery after a period of 1 week128 and 1 year.127

sec.title: Abdominal Wall
sec.p: By direct compression, IAH reduces abdominal wall blood flow, leading to fascial and muscle ischemia,129 which can decrease abdominal and chest wall compliance and further exacerbate IAH.80 Abdominal wall ischemia can lead to wound infections as well as complications of dehiscence and herniation. This has been best studied in the peritoneal dialysis patient population. Increased abdominal pressures are related to increased fill volumes. In addition to polycystic kidney disease, high BMI, and advanced age, high IAP has been identified as an independent risk factor for hernias and leaks in patients with peritoneal dialysis catheters.130 Del Peso et al showed that low daytime fill volumes and low intra-abdominal filling pressures may reduce the incidence of such complications.130 Intra-abdominal hypertension may also promote adhesion formation. In an animal study by de Souza et al, pneumoperitoneum and IAH induced peritoneal oxidative damage and adhesion formation in a graded fashion.131

sec.title: Treatment
sec.p: The best approach to ACS is prevention. This involves frequent IAP monitoring, determining accurate goal-directed resuscitation end points, and avoiding overresuscitation.132,133 In the setting of IAH, lactate levels, base deficit, and central venous oxygen saturations are all variables that may be used in guiding resuscitation. In contrast, urine output and central venous pressure may be misleading because they are directly affected by IAP as well as intravascular volume. Continuous RVEDVI, GEDVI, ITBV, and CI monitoring may be used as they are more precise measures of ventricular preload in the setting of IAH.77,83

Strategies aimed at reducing crystalloid resuscitation may avoid excessive volume administration and help prevent IAH. A meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials from the 1970s and 1980s failed to show any benefit of colloid versus crystalloid resuscitation for trauma and burns in terms of organ dysfunction and mortality overall, but there was a trend for decreased mortality in the trauma subgroup.134,135 Abdominal compartment syndrome was not recognized as a clinical entity until the mid 1980s, so whether colloid use may help limit fluid administration and prevent ACS is unknown.

Prevention of primary ACS in high-risk surgical patients often starts in the operating room with temporary abdominal closures that allow abdominal contents to expand freely as opposed to definitive fascial closures that can be restrictive.136 This concept of “staged damage-control laparotomy” has recently gained greater acceptance. Key to this concept is that prolonged operative time and extensive surgical repair in the setting of abdominal trauma, hemorrhage, or septic shock only invites the vicious cycle of hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy.137 In order to break this cycle and promote patient survival, surgical bleeding must be rapidly controlled and salvage procedures must be quickly applied followed by prompt temporary abdominal closure and expedited patient transfer to the intensive care unit.137 In nondamage-control cases (eg, stable patient with secondary peritonitis), the abdomen may need to be left open if the patient clearly demonstrates high PAPs on reapproximation of the fascia, predicting high risk of postoperative ACS. Raeburn et al, after examining several variables at the end of a laparotomy, found that only PAP is predictive of ACS development and does not preclude its development with bag closures.17 Temporary abdominal closure techniques include a towel clip skin closure with fascial edges not approximated; an opened sterile intravenous bag (Bogata bag) closure; a synthetic patch placement; a vacuum pack closure; and a modified sandwich-vacuum pack, using a 3-L urological irrigation bag and continuous high-pressure suction.138,139 While such temporary closures may reduce the incidence of ACS, they are not absolutely preventative. This has been reported with the use of the vacuum closures (Figure 1 ) which may so efficiently contain the abdominal contents that it allows for IAP increases with postoperative third-spacing and visceral edema.140 Because of this phenomenon, known as open abdomen ACS, it is imperative to allow for additional bowel swelling during temporary abdominal closure and to continue IAP monitoring in patients with open abdomens. For patients with open abdomens who do develop ACS, mortality is quite high. The IAH must be addressed promptly by releasing the temporary abdominal closure and allowing further expansion and eventration of the abdominal viscera prior to the placement of new abdominal closure drape.140 High crystalloid requirements (>10 L), may predict whom will go on to develop secondary ACS.140

The system is placed carefully (underlying bogata bag deep to fascial edges) with room for bowel expansion and edema to avoid the development of open abdomen ACS and enterocutaneous fistulas, with overlying VAC on low suction. sec.p: Intra-abdominal hypertension must be treated when ACS is clinically evident—that is, when IAP is greater than 20 to 25 mm Hg in association with hypotension, raised airway pressures, impaired ventilation, or oliguria. Treatment of IAH of 15 to 20 mm Hg must be considered in high-risk patients prior to the clinical onset of ACS. Examples include patients with intractable ICH or those with clinical evidence of intestinal ischemia (low ipH, high serum d-lactate levels in the setting of adequate blood pressure, or dusky bowel seen through a silastic closure).

The definitive treatment of IAH is DL.141 The treatment is almost always effective typically associated with a rapid improvement in airway pressures, partial pressure of oxygen in the alveoli/fraction of inspired oxygen (Pao 2/Fio 2) ratio, and urine output,142 but the effects of DL on organ function are variable with mortality as a whole at 50%.141 In patients who are clinically unstable, it may be performed at the bedside.143 Some authors have suggested using volume, mannitol, and/or sodium bicarbonate prior to DL to counteract the sudden drop in vascular resistance and the possible visceral reperfusion injury72; however, this strategy remains controversial.144

When the patient is ready for abdominal closure (hemodynamically stable, resolved sepsis, and reduced IAPs), removal of excess fluids by diuresis or hemofiltration is critical in reducing tissue edema and allowing wound closure. While the opportunity for primary fascial closure varies from one patient to another, generally it is not possible after 7 days due to the development of significant adhesions and granulation tissue that produce a “frozen abdomen.” Primary fascial closure is more likely with sequential incremental closures or with increasing tension on the temporary closure as edema resolves.145–147 Definitive fascial closure may be possible in a delayed setting with component separation (CS).148,149 If fascial closure is not possible, then the wound may be closed with an allograft (Alloderm) or a xenograft (Strattice/Permacol) with or without CS.150,151 Short-term follow-up in these patients have suggested a high rate of hernia formation and increased closure costs. Alternatively, the wound may be allowed to close by secondary intention, with expectation of hernia development. Healing and closure in those cases can be expedited with the use of a vacuum-assisted closure device59,146 or partial-thickness skin grafting,152 once enough healthy granulation tissue has bridged the wound.

While abdominal decompression initially decreases patient perception of physical, social, and emotional health, subsequent abdominal wall reconstruction restores patient’s physical and mental health. Abdominal decompression does not prevent return to gainful employment and should not be considered a permanently disabling condition.153

Open abdomens are associated with a 20% to 78% rate of unsuccessful reclosure in addition to a high risk of enterocutaneous fistulas and ventral hernias. In an attempt to avoid these complications, clinicians have pursued alternative methods to IAP reduction. Invasive alternatives to DL include paracentesis (for patients with large amounts of ascites) and endoscopic CS. For the former approach, bedside ultrasound may be helpful in identifying a safe window for catheter placement. While paracentesis has been reported to be a successful treatment for ACS in burn patients,154,155 animal studies have shown it to be ineffective in reducing cerebral hypertension associated with IAH.156 Paracentesis, in the few times that it is successful, produces a prompt and impressive clinical response; when that does not happen following catheter placement or if IAH recurs due to catheter malfunction, a more definitive treatment (ie, DL) must be considered. In endoscopic CS, the abdominal fascia is released through small laparoscopic skin incisions. While yet to be studied on humans, this “low-morbidity” approach has been shown to be feasible and effective in a porcine model of IAH.157 However, the effectiveness of this approach is likely to be short-term since the intact skin limits abdominal expansion and promotes increases in IAP.

There is a myriad of noninvasive treatment options for raised IAH (Table 7 ). Sedation and neuromuscular blockade are the mainstay medical therapy for IAH. The effect of paralysis on IAP has been documented in the literature to postpone increases in IAP.158,159 Opioids, on the other hand, may acutely raise IAP by promoting active phasic expiration.160 As long as visceral perfusion and oxygen delivery is not compromised, removal of excessive fluids by diuresis, hemofiltration, and/or ultrafiltration is another effective medical treatment for IAH. In patients with significant gaseous bowel distension, the use of prokinetics, nasogastric decompression, rectal drainage, or enemas may sustain minor reductions in IAP. These approaches, however, must be used cautiously in patients with bowel pathology. Similarly, avoiding acute hip flexion and positioning the patient in a reverse trendelenburg, prone, or semi-recumbent position may prevent further increases in the IAP. One last noninvasive option is the use of CNAP to the abdominal wall. While at this time there is limited experience with this technique on humans, animal studies suggest that the method is effective in reducing elevated intra-abdominal and cerebral pressures associated with IAH.57

Achieved with frequent IAP monitoring, determining accurate goal-directed resuscitation end points, avoiding overresuscitation with crystalloids, and temporary abdominal closures
Diuresis, hemofiltration, and/or ultrafiltration very effective if blood pressure tolerates
Paracentesis ineffective
Sedation and neuromuscular blockade extremely useful
Avoid excessive opiate use
Limited experience available with the use of continuous negative applied pressure (CNAP)
Prokinetics, nasogastric decompression, rectal drainage, and enemas are of limited effectiveness

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The prompt diagnosis and management of IAH is critical to the management of patients at risk of ACS. Routine and frequent IAP measuring is the cornerstone of this approach. These measurements allow for prompt medical therapy before the negative consequences of ACS occur and allow for surgical decompression or other less invasive procedures before end organ damage develops. The early recognition of IAH also avoids underresuscitation by recognizing artificially elevated filling pressures. The early detection of IAH may also provide therapeutic options for patients with intractable ICH. The pathophysiological consequences of IAH are significant and, if left untreated, often progress to MOF and death.
